TopicTitle: [WIP] Ascending Velocity - Do not go too fast on lift off!

Articles.Content:
Hi,

While working on my other plugin (Mass Relay), I searched for a plugin that will tell you if you are accelerating too slow (fighting gravity too much) or too hard (fighting air resistance), so I decided to try to find it on the forum, with no luck.

Sooo...

Let's do this

I tried using real data of atmospheric pressure and altitude and drag and and...

Well I don't want to be dead precise, so a good approximation should be enough.

Ence, the fabulous trendline get from a terminal velocity table (for Kerbin - at first) that I get somewhere...

And I will try adding something like a slider next to the throttle that will tell you if you are in the green zone, or too slow/too quick.

Tell me quickly if something like that already exists, I couldn't find it, but as a french I have trouble finding the correct search words
People make stuff like that with kOS. I do not believe there is a plugin that does it for you.
MechJeb can do this. Well, you can ask it to limit your throttle so that you don't exceed terminal velocity. A separate mod might be handy for people who don't like MechJeb.

Especially that it will be a part-free plugin. No risk of destroying your save file with unloaded ships if the plugin went missing.

Good news is I have a working plugin right now. (yeaaah, already).

Totally not user friendly, it's just a windows filled with debug data, but I have the info that I need. All I have to do now is making a pretty interface for it.
Sounds good, just don't forget to work on both
Make your mod work with FAR! Mechjeb terminal velocity limiter doesn't work with FAR

If it works with FAR, it will have to work with dynamic drag values rather than some strict pressure value. Probably just pull the Q value from FAR's in flight data and have the player set the max Q value.
The Engineer Redux mod displays this as "atmospheric efficiency".

I promise I will take a look at the real simulation drag force so that I can tell the "real" terminal velocity, using the FAR or the KSP model.

For now I will just give an approximation just to see where it gets me.
